titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Projects FA733

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-11-22 01:52:37 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Projects

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.
Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Although Project Files are recorded for 4,237 projects in the Fund File Index, the Ford archive's series of Project Files on microfilm currently only includes 984 Project Files (plus 1 NY Fund file, NY-79). Some of the missing 3,253 Project Files were renumbered as Grant Files (with 'PA' numbers) after 1953, but the majority of the missing files seem to have been destroyed.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Project files are indexed in the Ford Foundation's Central Index cards, 1950-1974 (FA736). However, not every Project file recorded in the Central Index is included in the Ford archives.

The Ford Foundation's Central Index, Master Cards â€“ Projects (FA736) provides descriptions of Project files numbered 'NY-1' to 'NY-166', and 'A-1' to 'E-199', and is arranged by Project number. The 'Master Cards' for Project files provide the only remaining detailed description of the destroyed Project files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Most of the remaining Project files document project proposals rejected by the Ford Foundation from 1950-1964. Project files for accepted proposals were re-numbered as Grant files, with a Program Action (PA) number. The new Grant file number (PA number) is noted on the Ford Foundation's 'Central Index (FA736), Master Cards - Projects' cards, under the old Project number.

The exception being the 'Ford Foundation initiated' projects, which remained as Project files after being approved. For instance, "C-488: Social Sciences and Business Administration (Ford Foundation initiated, 1958".

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Project Files are housed on 41 reels of 16mm microfilm numbered P-1000 to P-1040.
Project Files are arranged and identified by an alphanumeric Project number beginning with the letters A thru E, followed by a sequential number between 1 and 1000 (for example: A-001 to E-999).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

did.unittitle: A-60: Thessalonica Agricultural and Industrial Institute (American Farm School)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Project to extend the service of the American Farm School in Salonica, Greece, through systematic follow-up and assistance to its graduates, for the purpose of increasing agricultura production and improving standards of living in their rural communities.

B-20: Pilot Project in Elementary Education - Saudi Arabia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Preliminary development of this project must include the following: (1) initial definition of the project itself, and (2) preliminary negotiations paving the way for the visit of a high-level group which it is suggested include Mr. Henry Ford II, to negotiate directly with the King of Saudi Arabia on the project.

did.unittitle: B-29: Social Science Research Council: Survey of Research on Conservation and Resources

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To make a survey of Research on Conservation and Resources in government - federal and state - and in colleges and universities; the survey of federal government research will be made by Dr. Arthur Maass in Washington by direct contact with the federal agencies, and the survey of state research will be made by questions circularized to the states through the Council of State Governments and the Association of State Planning and Development Agencies.

did.unittitle: B-30: The Conservation Foundation: Survey of Conservation Education

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To arrange for the preparation of a series of papers on conservation education and to synthesize in a brief report o the Ford Foundation the most important views expressed in the papers and to give the Conservation Foundation's assessment of the overall situation; also to assist in the review of papers at a meeting of the National Committee on Policies in Conservation Education.

did.unittitle: B-31: University of Chicago: Gaps in Resources and Conservation Research

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To support Dr. Schultz's activities on the identification of gaps in resources and conservation research; for assistants and to gring colleagues to Chicago for conferences; and for the work of his seminar.

did.unittitle: B-32: Social Science Research Council: Research Liaison Office - Middle East and Southern Asia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To aid an assist in a general way a wide range of people coming into the area for work and study, and to give more specialized help to research students in their special fields.

did.unittitle: B-45: Social Science Research Council, American Political Science Association, Public Administration Clearing House, National Planning Association, National Civil Service League, and National League of Women Voters: Commission of Inquiry on Public Service Personnel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To establish a Commission on the Public Service, composed of nationally representative leading citizens, to make a basic re-examinational and restatement of the concepts upon which our public service is to be built; the basic purpose of such a restatement would be to provide the guidelines for public policies which will (1) preserve our substantial gains against the patronage system, and (2) move public personnel management forward toward the goals of a more responsible and more flexible public service.

relatedmaterial.p: See Ford Foundation grant number 05400093 for subsequent material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Project description: "Grants-in-aid program to about five teams to theater people headed by a designer who would carry the project through to the drafting and model stage, and perhaps then come together in an exhibit to be assisted by the Ford Foundation".
Grantees include:
Ralph Alswang (designer) and Paul Rudolph (architect), â€“ development of a theater using new film projection techniques and live stage action simultaneously.
Eldon Elder (designer) and Edward Durell Stone (architect) â€“ design of a 2,000 seat outdoor theater.
Barrie Greenbie (designer) and Seth Hiller (architect) â€“ design of an ideal theater for the modern dance.
David Hays (designer) and Peter Blake (architect) â€“ design of a 299 seat open-stage theater.

George C. Izenour (designer) and Paul Schwikher (architect) â€“ development of a theater complex comprising one theater convertible among proscenium, Elizabethan, and arena-stage forms, and an experimental space controlled by an analogue and digital computer.
Frederick J. Kiesler (architect and designer) working with playwrights and mechanical engineers â€“ design of a flexible urban theater adaptable to both classical and experimental plays.
Jo Mielziner (designer) and Edward L. Barnes (architect) â€“ design of an ideal theater to house 'intimate music-drama' outside the traditional operatic and musical-comedy forms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Approval of appropriation for a five-year program of matching grants to American museums for the publication of catalogues of their visual arts collections. $475,000 for 5 years. Includes correspondence to/from Andrew Carnduff Ritchie (1907-1978).

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also files documenting grants for publication of catalogues made to Founders Society Detroit Institute of Arts (06700126, PA67-126), Wichita Art Museum (06900535, PA69-535), Bates College (06900536, PA69-536), and Museum of Fine Arts (06900537, PA69-537).

D-495: Grants-In-Aid to talented Artists (Ford Foundation initiated)

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See also: Ford Foundation records, Grants, 06290107 (PA92-107), Foundation-Administered Project (FAP), "PURCHASES UNDER THE FOUNDATION'S PROGRAM FOR THE PURCHASE OF WORKS BY AMERICAN ARTISTS".
See also: Ford Foundation records, Projects, D-497: Collaboration of painters and sculptors in production designs of local theater and opera groups.
See also: Ford Foundation records, Projects, D-498: Opportunities for professional, community and academic choral directors.
See also: Ford Foundation records, Projects, D-499: Solo artists program to commission and arrange performances of new works.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six programs are included in this appropriation:
(1) 3-year purchase program for painters and sculptors (Ford Foundation grant 06290107, PA62-107);
(2) Program to provide talented young singers with opportunities to perform leading roles with civic opera companies;
(3) 3-year program of administrative internships in professional and community opera, symphony and theater groups;
(4) Collaboration of painters and sculptors in production designs of local theater and opera groups (D-497);
(5) Opportunities for professional, community and academic choral directors (D-498);
(6) Solo artists program to commission and arrange performances of new works (D-499).
